title: Choose the right environment
body: Use prod for live deployments so caches and logging run in production mode. Keep dev for local/staging instances where debug output is acceptable.

title: Tagline
body: Optional subtitle displayed in themes and emails. Leave blank if you prefer a minimal header.

title: Deployment environment
body: Pick prod when preparing a real instance so Doctrine and cache behave optimally. dev keeps verbose logging for local workstations.

title: Default timezone
body: Tasks, publishing windows, and cron-style jobs use this timezone unless overridden per project.

title: Generate a strong secret
body: If you leave the secret empty the installer will generate one automatically. Copy it to your password manager so you can rotate it later via bin/init.

title: Debug mode
body: Leaving debug enabled in production reveals stack traces and slows down responses. Toggle it off outside staging or development boxes.

title: Default URL
body: Point this to the canonical HTTPS origin so generated links in emails and CLI commands stay consistent.

title: Instance name
body: The name appears on the admin shell and emails. You can change it later under system settings.

title: Support email
body: Used for password reset and help desk notifications. Make sure the mailbox is monitored before inviting users.

title: Locale and timezone
body: Locale drives translations and formatting defaults, timezone becomes the baseline for scheduling and publication windows.

title: Self-registration
body: Enable only if you plan to gate access with invitations or moderation; otherwise keep new account creation restricted to administrators.

title: Maintenance mode
body: When enabled, visitors see a friendly maintenance page while admins continue working behind the scenes.

title: Plan storage ahead
body: Point the storage root at a filesystem with regular backups. The installer will create databases/, uploads/, snapshots/, and backups/ folders underneath.

title: Writable directories
body: The web user must be able to create directories under the chosen storage root. Double-check permissions with ls -la if the diagnostics step still shows warnings.

title: Secure the first administrator
body: Pick a strong password that follows the configured policy and enable MFA if possible. Recovery contacts help regain access if MFA devices are lost.

title: Primary administrator email
body: Use a shared team inbox or on-call email so multiple people can access the first admin account if needed.

title: Display name
body: Choose a friendly label—this shows up in activity feeds and notification emails.

title: Password policy
body: The installer enforces the policy defined in core.users.password_policy. Use a passphrase that includes numbers, mixed case, and special characters for best results.

title: Preferred locale
body: The admin UI will default to this locale once the user signs in; they can change it later in their profile.

title: Preferred timezone
body: The timezone drives scheduling widgets and dashboard timestamps for this user.

title: Require MFA
body: Enforce multi-factor setup during the first login to harden the account immediately.

title: Recovery contacts
body: Recovery email and phone are optional but help regain access if MFA devices are lost—store them carefully.

title: Recovery phone
body: Use an SMS-capable number that the security team controls; avoid personal numbers for shared administrator accounts.

title: Troubleshoot missing extensions
body: Missing PHP extensions can often be installed via your package manager (e.g. apt install php-intl). Re-run diagnostics after installing to confirm they are loaded.

title: Filesystem check
body: If a directory is marked as not writable, create it manually and run chmod/chown so PHP can write caches and database files.

title: Review before finalising
body: Double-check that email addresses, base URL, and storage root are correct. The installer will lock itself after completion; use the summary as your final checklist.

title: Download configuration
body: After finalisation, copy the contents of .env.local and store them securely (secrets manager or vault). This makes rotating environments easier later.
